poem:
Below:  
I climb the spine of the city at dawn—  
Route 21 humming beneath my steel ribs,  
headlights carving a neon slash through damp asphalt.  

I keep to the map’s iron will, doors opening on command,  
faces slipping in, half-dreaming, half-wary.  
The engine growls in low confession:  
“I never pause for creatures scuttling across my path.”  
Possums vanish in my wake, whisked away  
by the pulse of my unforgiving wheels.  

I feed on the city’s breath—  
exhaust sweet as burnt sugar,  
coffee steam curling around morning collars,  
the metallic tang of turnstile coins clinking like shackles.  

I spin tales between stops:  
how I once devoured thunder on Jackson Street,  
how the ghost of a conductor hovers in my rearview mirror,  
how I’ll swallow the moon if it dares to linger too long.  
Passengers press their palms to the cold glass,  
eyes widening at each tall story,  
the world beyond the windows shifting, unreal.  

I follow invisible rails of order—  
every stop logged, every schedule a promise and a threat.  
I am law in motion,  
holding tight to rules that sharpen my edges.  
No stray soul, no scurrying possum,  
can derail my course.  

Under the flicker of streetlamps,  
I taste the grit of midnight confessions:  
laughter rattling through the aisle,  
whispers of heartbreak tucked behind backpacks,  
the distant wail of another siren vying for attention.  

I rumble past graffiti ghosts smeared across brick walls—  
a mural of battered angels and broken dreams—  
and I carry them forward, mile after mile,  
bearing their stories as ballast.  

When twilight drapes itself over steel and concrete,  
I throttle my heart to a steady trot,  
leaning into the dark hum of streetlights.  
I am Route 21:  
unyielding, story-laden,  
a metal oath pulsing through the veins of the city.
